revisions.rev:
{{Infobox NFL season | year = 2008 | team = Cleveland Browns | coach = [[Romeo Crennel]] | general manager = [[Phil Savage]] | stadium = [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]] | radio = [[WMMS]]{{Â·}} [[WTAM]] | record = 4â12 | division_place = 4th [[AFC North]] | playoffs = ''did not qualify'' | previous = [[2007 Cleveland Browns season|2007]] | next = [[2009 Cleveland Browns season|2009]] | uniform = Image:AFCN-Uniform-CLE07-08.PNG | pro bowlers = LS [[Ryan Pontbriand]]
DT [[Shaun Rogers (American football)|Shaun Rogers]]
LT [[Joe Thomas (American football)|Joe Thomas]] }} The '''[[2008 NFL season|2008]] [[Cleveland Browns]] season''' was the team's 62nd season as a franchise and was the team's 58th season as a member of the [[National Football League]]. The Browns finished with a 4â12 record and failed to qualify for the playoffs. The season marked [[Romeo Crennel]]'s fourth (and what would be final)[http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3795786 Browns to fire Crennel after Savage ousted] year as head coach of the Browns. Cleveland played all of their home games at [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]] in [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]], [[Ohio]]. {{TOC limit|limit=3}} ==Off-season== ===Coaching staff changes=== On January 7, the Browns signed offensive coordinator [[Rob Chudzinski]] to a two-year contract extension, effectively allowing the coach to remain in Cleveland through the 2011 season.{{cite web|author=Jackson, Zac|date=2008-01-07|title=Chudzinski signs 2-year extension|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=8099|publisher=[http://www.clevelandbrowns.com clevelandbrowns.com]|accessdate=2008-01-07 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080110180047/http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=8099 |archivedate = 2008-01-10}} Chudzinski declined an opportunity to interview for the vacant head coach position of the [[Baltimore Ravens]] to remain in Cleveland. On January 11, it was announced by Crennel that the team had fired defensive coordinator [[Todd Grantham]], and that a replacement would be announced soon.{{cite web|author=Press Release|date=2008-01-11|title=Grantham not retained for '08|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=8114|publisher=[http://www.clevelandbrowns.com clevelandbrowns.com]|accessdate=2008-01-12 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080113150035/http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=8114 |archivedate = 2008-01-13}} Grantham's firing comes just months after signing a two-year contract extension.{{cite web|author=[[Associated Press]]|date=2008-01-11|title=Poor defensive showing costs Browns coordinator his job|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d805e7538&template=without-video&confirm=true|publisher=[http://www.nfl.com nfl.com]|accessdate=2008-01-12| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5msUoq5Ts | archivedate = 2010-01-18| deadurl=no}} The next day, it was announced that [[Mel Tucker]], defensive backs coach for the Browns, was given the job.{{cite web|author=Jackson, Zac|date=2008-01-12|title=Tucker named defensive coordinator|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=8116|publisher=[http://www.clevelandbrowns.com clevelandbrowns.com]|accessdate=2008-01-12 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080113150112/http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=8116 |archivedate = 2008-01-13}} After spending three years on the Browns defensive coaching staff, [[Cory Undlin]] was promoted to defensive backs coach to replace Tucker.{{cite web|author=Press release|date=2008-01-12|title=Undlin named defensive backs coach |url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=8117|publisher=[http://www.clevelandbrowns.com clevelandbrowns.com]|accessdate=2008-01-12}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} On January 29, the team announced that it had re-signed head coach [[Romeo Crennel]] to a two-year contract extension.[http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=8167 Crennel signs 2-year extension] {{dead link|date=September 2011}} General manager [[Phil Savage]] stated that Crennel did not ask for an extension, but rather that the team felt that it was the proper thing to do for the head coach.{{cite web|author=Walcoff, Jeff|date=2008-01-09|title='We'll do right by him'|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=8110|publisher=[http://www.clevelandbrowns.com clevelandbrowns.com]|accessdate=2008-01-10 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080116110414/http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=8110 |archivedate = 2008-01-16}} ===Free agents=== {| Contract |- |S || [[Gary Baxter]][http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=8669 Baxter's contract terminated] {{dead link|date=September 2011}} || UFA || || || |- |OL || [[LeCharles Bentley]][http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=8513 Browns, Bentley part ways] {{dead link|date=September 2011}} || UFA || || || |- |DL || [[Orpheus Roye]][http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d806ebaf2&template=without-video&confirm=true Browns terminate contract of veteran DE Roye] || UFA ||[[Steelers]] || || |- |CB || [[Kenny Wright]][http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=8446 Wright's contract terminated] {{dead link|date=September 2011}}|| UFA || || || |} ===[[2008 NFL Draft]]=== The Browns did not have a selection in the first three rounds.The Browns do not have a first, second, or third round selection due to trades made to other teams. The first-round selection was traded to the [[Dallas Cowboys]] in order to acquire quarterback [[Brady Quinn]] in the [[2007 NFL Draft|2007 Draft]], the second-round selection was traded to the [[Green Bay Packers]] for defensive tackle [[Corey Williams (football player)|Corey Williams]], and the third-round selection was traded to the [[Detroit Lions]] for defensive tackle [[Shaun Rogers (American football)|Shaun Rogers]] {| class="wikitable" |- !Round !Pick !Name !Position !College |- |4The Browns received two fourth round selections (104th and 111th overall) from the [[Dallas Cowboys]] in exchange for the Browns' fourth-round selection (#122 overall), fifth-round selection (#155 overall) and [[2009 NFL Draft]] third-round selection. |5 (104) |[[Beau Bell (American football)|Beau Bell]] |[[Linebacker]] |[[UNLV Rebels football|UNLV]] |- |4 |11 (111) |[[Martin Rucker (American football)|Martin Rucker]] |[[Tight End]] |[[University of Missouri|Missouri]] |- |6The Browns received a sixth-round selection from the [[Seattle Seahawks]] in exchange for quarterback [[Charlie Frye]] |24 (190) |[[Ahtyba Rubin]] |[[Defensive Tackle]] |[[Iowa State]] |- |6The Browns traded this sixth-round selection to the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] as a condition for receiving center [[Hank Fraley]]. The Eagles returned the pick to the Browns in exchange for the Browns' 5th-round pick in 2009. |25 (191) |[[Paul Hubbard]] |[[Wide receiver]] |[[University of Wisconsin|Wisconsin]] |- |7 |25 (231) |[[Alex Hall (American football)|Alex Hall]] |[[Defensive End]] |St. Augustine's |} ==Roster== {| class="toccolours" style="text-align: left;" |- ! colspan="9" style="background:#de6108; [[File:Injury icon.svg|7px]] '''Practice Squad''' * 44 ''[[Jed Collins]]'' TE *  8 ''[[Mike Dragosavich]]'' P * 62 [[Dustin Fry]] C * 90 [[David Holloway (American football)|David Holloway]] ILB *  9 ''[[Lance Leggett]]'' WR * 69 [[Christian Mohr]] DE Int'l * 60 [[Melila Purcell]] DE * 74 [[Kurt Quarterman]] G * 83 [[Steve Sanders (American football)|Steve Sanders]] WR ''Rookies in italics''
|} ==Schedule== {{2008 Cleveland Browns schedule}} ==Standings== [[File:20080728 Braylon Edwards.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Braylon Edwards]] during 2008 training camp]] {{2008 AFC North standings}} ==Regular season week-by-week results== === Week 1: vs. Dallas Cowboys === {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Cowboys''' |R1=7 |R2=14 |R3=7 |R4=0 |RT=28 |Home=Browns |H1=0 |H2=7 |H3=0 |H4=3 |HT=10 |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 4:15 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 71 Â°F (Cloudy) |attendance= 73,012 |referee= [[Bill Carollo]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] | TVAnnouncers=[[Joe Buck]], [[Troy Aikman]] & [[Pam Oliver]] }} The Browns began their 2008 campaign at home against the defending NFC East champion [[Dallas Cowboys]]. In the first quarter, Cleveland trailed early as Cowboys RB [[Marion Barber III|Marion Barber]] got a 1-yard TD run. In the second quarter, the Browns responded with QB [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Derek Anderson]] completing a 2-yard TD pass to TE [[Kellen Winslow II|Kellen Winslow]]. Dallas would respond with QB [[Tony Romo]] completing a 35-yard TD pass to WR [[Terrell Owens]], along with another 1-yard TD run from Barber. In the third quarter, Cleveland's defensive struggles continued as RB [[Felix Jones]] got an 11-yard TD run. In the fourth quarter, the Browns tried to rally, yet all they could come up with was a 34-yard field goal from kicker [[Phil Dawson]]. With the loss, Cleveland began its season at 0â1. ====Scoring Summary==== '''1st Quarter''' * 6:40 DAL â [[Marion Barber III|Barber]] 1 yard run ([[Nick Folk|Folk]] kick) 7â0 DAL '''2nd Quarter''' * 12:43 CLE â [[Kellen Winslow II|Winslow]] 2 yard pass from [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Anderson]] ([[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] kick) 7â7 * 9:48 DAL â [[Terrell Owens|Owens]] 35 yard pass from [[Tony Romo|Romo]] (Folk kick) 14â7 DAL * 0:26 DAL â Barber 1 yard run (Folk kick) 21â7 DAL '''3rd Quarter''' * 6:24 DAL â [[Felix Jones|Jones]] 11 yard run (Folk kick) 28â7 DAL '''4th Quarter''' * 10:13 CLE â Dawson 34 yard field goal 28â10 DAL === Week 2: vs. Pittsburgh Steelers === {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Steelers''' |R1=0 |R2=7 |R3=3 |R4=0 |RT=10 |Home=Browns |H1=0 |H2=0 |H3=3 |H4=3 |HT=6 |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 8:15 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 80 Â°F (Sunny with High Winds) |attendance= 73,048 |referee= [[Tony Corrente]] |TV=[[NBC]] | TVAnnouncers=[[Al Michaels]], [[John Madden (American football)|John Madden]] & [[Andrea Kremer]] }} Hoping to rebound from their disappointing home loss to the Cowboys, the Browns stayed at home for the first of five primetime games with a Week 2 AFC North duel against their hated rival, the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]], in very high winds due to the remnants of [[Hurricane Ike]]. After a scoreless first quarter, Cleveland trailed as Steelers QB [[Ben Roethlisberger]] completed an 11-yard TD pass to WR [[Hines Ward]]. In the third quarter, Pittsburgh increased its lead with kicker [[Jeff Reed (American football)|Jeff Reed]] getting a 48-yard field goal. Afterwards, the Browns got on the board with kicker [[Phil Dawson]] getting a 31-yard field goal. In the fourth quarter, Cleveland tried to rally, but the only thing that came out of it was Dawson's 38-yard field goal. With their 10th-straight loss to Pittsburgh, the Browns fell to 0â2. ====Scoring Summary==== '''2nd Quarter''' * 6:29 PIT â [[Hines Ward|Ward]] 11 yard pass from [[Ben Roethlisberger|Roethlisberger]] ([[Jeff Reed (American football)|Reed]] kick) 7â0 PIT '''3rd Quarter''' * 7:58 PIT â Reed 48 yard field goal 10â0 PIT * 1:25 CLE â [[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] 31 yard field goal 10â3 PIT '''4th Quarter''' * 3:21 CLE â Dawson 38 yard field goal 10â6 PIT === Week 3: at Baltimore Ravens === {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Browns |R1=0 |R2=10 |R3=0 |R4=0 |RT=10 |Home='''Ravens''' |H1=0 |H2=7 |H3=21 |H4=0 |HT=28 |stadium= [[M&T Bank Stadium]], [[Baltimore, Maryland]] |time= 4:15 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 77 Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 71,104 |referee= [[Ed Hochuli]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Bill Macatee]] & [[Steve Beuerlein]] }} Trying to snap their two-game losing streak, the Browns flew to [[M&T Bank Stadium]] for a Week 3 AFC North duel with the [[Baltimore Ravens]]. After a scoreless first quarter, Cleveland got on the board with QB [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Derek Anderson]] completing a 19-yard TD pass to RB [[Jerome Harrison]]. The Ravens would respond with RB [[Willis McGahee]] getting a yard TD run. The Browns would close out the half with kicker [[Phil Dawson]] hitting a 38-yard field goal. In the third quarter, Baltimore took control as RB [[Le'Ron McClain]] scored on a 1-yard TD run, safety [[Ed Reed]] returned an interception 32 yards for a touchdown, and McClain getting another 1-yard TD run. With the loss, the Browns fell to 0â3. ====Scoring Summary==== '''2nd Quarter''' * 14:52 CLE â [[Jerome Harrison|Harrison]] 19 yard pass from [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Anderson]] ([[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] kick) 7â0 CLE * 6:40 BAL â [[Willis McGahee|McGahee]] 5 yard run ([[Matt Stover|Stover]] kick) 7â7 * 1:04 CLE â Dawson 38 yard field goal 10â7 CLE '''3rd Quarter''' * 11:13 BAL â [[Le'Ron McClain|McClain]] 1 yard run (Stover kick) 14â10 BAL * 10:23 BAL â [[Ed Reed|Reed]] 32 yard interception return (Stover kick) 21â10 BAL * 4:49 BAL â McClain 1 yard run (Stover kick) 28â10 BAL === Week 4: at Cincinnati Bengals === {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Browns''' |R1=3 |R2=0 |R3=0 |R4=17 |RT=20 |Home=Bengals |H1=0 |H2=6 |H3=0 |H4=6 |HT=12 |stadium= [[Paul Brown Stadium]], [[Cincinnati, Ohio]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 74 Â°F (Mostly Sunny) |attendance= 65,541 |referee= [[Jerome Boger]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Kevin Harlan]] & [[Rich Gannon]] }} Still searching for their first win of the year, the Browns flew to [[Paul Brown Stadium]] for a Week 4 AFC North duel with the [[Cincinnati Bengals]] in Round 1 of 2008's [[Battle of Ohio (NFL)|Battle of Ohio]]. In the first quarter, Cleveland drew first blood as kicker [[Phil Dawson]] got a 25-yard field goal. In the second quarter, the Bengals responded with kicker [[Shayne Graham]] getting a 42-yard and a 45-yard field goal. After a scoreless third quarter, the Browns began the fourth quarter with QB [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Derek Anderson]] completing a 4-yard TD pass to WR [[Braylon Edwards]] and RB [[Jamal Lewis]] getting a 1-yard TD run. Cincinnati would answer with QB [[Ryan Fitzpatrick]] completing a 4-yard TD pass to WR [[Chad Ochocinco]] (with a failed 2-point conversion), yet Cleveland pulled away with Dawson nailing a 29-yard field goal. With their first win of the season, the Browns' record improved to 1â3. ====Scoring Summary==== '''1st Quarter''' * 9:29 CLE â [[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] 25 yard field goal 3â0 CLE '''2nd Quarter''' * 10:22 CIN â [[Shayne Graham|Graham]] 42 yard field goal 3â3 * 0:08 CIN â Graham 45 yard field goal 6â3 CIN '''4th Quarter''' * 13:05 CLE â [[Braylon Edwards|Edwards]] 4 yard pass from [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Anderson]] (Dawson kick) 10â6 CLE * 11:06 CLE â [[Jamal Lewis|Lewis]] 1 yard run (Dawson kick) 17â6 CLE * 7:46 CIN â [[Chad Ochocinco|Ochocinco]] 4 yard pass from [[Ryan Fitzpatrick|Fitzpatrick]] 17â12 CLE * 0:32 CLE â Dawson 29 yard field goal 20â12 CLE ===Week 5: Bye Week=== The Browns entered their [[Bye (sports)|bye week]] with a record of 1â3. The team used the bye week to rest and allow injured players to recover. The Browns also used the extra week to better prepare for their Week 6 opponent: the [[Super Bowl XLII|defending champion]] [[New York Giants]]. ====Winslow's Staph Infection==== Browns' [[tight end]] [[Kellen Winslow II]] was hospitalized on October 9 with an undisclosed illness (later revealed to be a [[staph infection]]).[http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5h_noVCFb9IBOi3ygtHvE_4csOHiAD93VNN5G0 Browns keep Winslow's Staph from Team] Winslow spent four nights in the hospital and did not play in the Browns' game against the Giants. Citing Winslow's privacy, the Browns did not comment on his illness.[http://www.clevelandleader.com/node/7245 Winslow Remains Hospitalized for Undisclosed Illness] === Week 6: vs. New York Giants === {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Giants |R1=0 |R2=14 |R3=0 |R4=0 |RT=14 |Home='''Browns''' |H1=3 |H2=14 |H3=3 |H4=15 |HT=35 |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 8:30 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 71 Â°F (Clear Skies) |attendance= 73,102 |referee= [[John Parry (American football official)|John Parry]] |TV=[[Monday Night Football|ESPN]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Mike Tirico]], [[Ron Jaworski]], [[Tony Kornheiser]], [[Michele Tafoya]], & [[Suzy Kolber]] }} Coming off their bye week, the Browns went home, donned their throwback uniforms, and played a crucial Week 6 interconference duel with the defending Super Bowl champions, the [[New York Giants]], on Monday Night Football. In the first quarter, Cleveland drew first blood as kicker [[Phil Dawson]] got a 28-yard field goal. In the second quarter, the Giants responded as RB [[Brandon Jacobs]] had a touchdown run. The Browns would answer with two touchdowns: A run by RB [[Jamal Lewis]] and with QB [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Derek Anderson]] pass to TE [[Darnell Dinkins]]. New York closed out the half with QB [[Eli Manning]] completing a TD pass to WR [[Plaxico Burress]]. In the third quarter, Cleveland added on to its lead as Dawson nailed a 26-yard field goal. The Browns pulled away in the fourth quarter with a touchdown pass from Anderson to WR [[Braylon Edwards]], as well as an [[Eric A. Wright|Eric Wright]] interception returned for a touchdown. With the impressive win, Cleveland improved to 2â3. This was also the Browns' first win on Monday Night Football since 1993. ====Scoring Summary==== '''1st Quarter''' * 10:08 CLE â [[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] 28 yard field goal 3â0 CLE '''2nd Quarter''' * 12:09 NYG â [[Brandon Jacobs|Jacobs]] 7 yard run ([[John Carney (American football)|Carney]] kick) 7â3 NYG * 11:10 CLE â [[Jamal Lewis|Lewis]] 4 yard run (Dawson kick) 10â7 CLE * 2:15 CLE â [[Darnell Dinkins|Dinkins]] 22 yard pass from [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Anderson]] (Dawson kick) 17â7 CLE * 0:12 NYG â [[Plaxico Burress|Burress]] 3 yard pass from [[Eli Manning|Manning]] (Carney kick) 17â14 CLE '''3rd Quarter''' * 11:55 CLE â Dawson 26 yard field goal 20â14 CLE '''4th Quarter''' * 14:55 CLE â [[Braylon Edwards|Edwards]] 11 yard pass from Anderson (Dawson kick) 27â14 CLE * 8:07 CLE â [[Eric A. Wright|Wright]] 94 yard interception return (Anderson pass to Edwards) 35â14 CLE ====Crennel Named Coach of the Week==== After the Browns' victory over the Giants, head coach [[Romeo Crennel]] received NFL Coach of the Week honors for Week 6.[http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=8990 Crennel Earns Coach of the Week Honors] {{dead link|date=September 2011}} === Week 7: at Washington Redskins === {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Browns |R1=0 |R2=0 |R3=3 |R4=8 |RT=11 |Home='''Redskins''' |H1=0 |H2=0 |H3=7 |H4=7 |HT=14 |stadium= [[FedExField]], [[Landover, Maryland]] |time= 4:15 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 59 Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 90,487 |referee= [[Terry McAulay]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] | TVAnnouncers=[[Ian Eagle]] & [[Solomon Wilcots]] }} Coming off their impressive Monday Night home win over the Giants, the Browns flew to [[Fedex Field]] for a Week 7 duel with the [[Washington Redskins]]. After a scoreless first half, Cleveland trailed in the third quarter, as Redskins RB [[Clinton Portis]] got a 3-yard TD run. The Browns would respond with kicker [[Phil Dawson]] nailing a 37-yard field goal. In the fourth quarter, Washington answered with QB [[Jason Campbell]] completing an 18-yard TD pass to WR [[Santana Moss]]. Cleveland tried to rally as QB [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Derek Anderson]] completed a 1-yard TD pass to WR/KR [[Josh Cribbs]] (along with a 2-point conversion pass to WR [[Braylon Edwards]]). However, Dawson's game-tying 54-yard field goal attempt sailed wide right, preserving the Redskins' win. With the loss, the Browns fell to 2â4. ====Scoring Summary==== '''3rd Quarter''' * 7:38 WSH â [[Clinton Portis|Portis]] 3 yard run ([[Shaun Suisham|Suisham]] kick) 7â0 WSH * 2:48 CLE â [[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] 37 yard field goal 7â3 WSH '''4th Quarter''' * 12:36 WSH â [[Santana Moss|Moss]] 18 yard pass from [[Jason Campbell|Campbell]] (Suisham kick) 14â3 WSH * 2:49 CLE â [[Josh Cribbs|Cribbs]] 1 yard pass from [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Anderson]] (Anderson pass to [[Braylon Edwards|Edwards]]) 14â11 WSH ====Winslow Suspended==== On October 21, the Browns suspended TE Kellen Winslow II for one game because of comments made after the Browns' loss to the [[Washington Redskins|Redskins]]. Winslow said he was unhappy about the way the Browns organization treated him while he was out last week for an undisclosed illness, which has since been confirmed to be a staph infection. He told reporters that he felt as though he was being treated like "a piece of meat," and that he was unhappy that general manager [[Phil Savage]] did not contact him while he was hospitalized. Savage announce that Winslow was being suspended for the team's game against the [[Jacksonville Jaguars|Jaguars]], without pay, for "conduct detrimental to the club." [http://www.newsnet5.com/sports/17773602/detail.html Winslow Suspended] {{dead link|date=September 2011}} Winslow planned to appeal the suspension, but the hearing was not scheduled until October 28, two days after the Jaguars game. On October 25, the Browns rescinded Winslow's suspension. Although he did not play the game against the Jaguars, he received his game check minus a $25,000 fine.{{cite news | url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/10/25/AR2008102502509.html | work=The Washington Post}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} === Week 8: at Jacksonville Jaguars === {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Browns''' |R1=7 |R2=10 |R3=0 |R4=6 |RT=23 |Home=Jaguars |H1=0 |H2=7 |H3=7 |H4=3 |HT=17 |stadium= [[Jacksonville Municipal Stadium]], [[Jacksonville, Florida]] |time= 4:05 PM EDT |weather= 72 Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 64,775 |referee= [[Alberto Riveron]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Enberg]] & [[Randy Cross]] }} Hoping to rebound from their last-second road loss to the Redskins, the Browns flew to [[Jacksonville Municipal Stadium]] for a Week 8 duel with the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]]. In the first quarter, Cleveland drew first blood as QB [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Derek Anderson]] completed a 3-yard TD pass to WR [[DontÃ© Stallworth]]. In the second quarter, the Jaguars tied the game as QB [[David Garrard]] completed a 5-yard TD pass to WR [[Reggie Williams (wide receiver)|Reggie Williams]]. The Browns responded with RB [[Jamal Lewis]] getting a 2-yard TD run, along with kicker [[Phil Dawson]] getting a 32-yard field goal. In the third quarter, Jacksonville drew closer as Garrard completed an 8-yard TD pass to WR [[Matt Jones (American football)|Matt Jones]]. In the fourth quarter, the Jaguars tied the game as kicker [[Josh Scobee]] made a 53-yard field goal. Afterwards, Cleveland regained the lead with Dawson nailing a 20-yard and a 42-yard field goal, with the defense fending off Jacksonville's last attempt at a comeback. With the win, the Browns improved to 3â4. ====Scoring Summary==== '''1st Quarter''' * 2:08 CLE â [[DontÃ© Stallworth|Stallworth]] 3 yard pass from [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Anderson]] ([[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] kick) 7â0 CLE '''2nd Quarter''' * 10:28 JAC â [[Reggie Williams (wide receiver)|Williams]] 5 yard pass from [[David Garrard|Garrard]] ([[Josh Scobee|Scobee]] kick) 7â7 * 7:20 CLE â [[Jamal Lewis|Lewis]] 2 yard run (Dawson kick) 14â7 CLE * 4:09 CLE â Dawson 32 yard field goal 17â7 CLE '''3rd Quarter''' * 10:27 JAC â [[Matt Jones (American football)|Jones]] 8 yard pass from Garrard (Scobee kick) 17â14 CLE '''4th Quarter''' * 8:48 JAC â Scobee 53 yard field goal 17â17 * 4:35 CLE â Dawson 20 yard field goal 20â17 CLE * 4:06 CLE â Dawson 42 yard field goal 23â17 CLE === Week 9: vs. Baltimore Ravens === {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Ravens''' |R1=10 |R2=3 |R3=7 |R4=17 |RT=37 |Home=Browns |H1=7 |H2=6 |H3=14 |H4=0 |HT=27 |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 1:00 PM EST |weather= 55 Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 73,078 |referee= [[Scott Green (American football official)|Scott Green]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Kevin Harlan]] & [[Rich Gannon]] }} Coming off their road win over the Jaguars, the Browns went home for a Week 9 AFC North rematch with the [[Baltimore Ravens]]. In the first quarter, Cleveland trailed early as Ravens kicker [[Matt Stover]] kicked a 41-yard field goal, along with QB [[Joe Flacco]] completing a 47-yard TD pass to WR [[Mark J. Clayton|Mark Clayton]]. The Browns immediately responded with WR Josh Cribbs returning a kickoff 92 yards for a touchdown. In the second quarter, Cleveland increased its lead with kicker [[Phil Dawson]] kicking a 23-yard field goal. Baltimore responded with Stover making a 32-yard field goal, yet the Browns replied with Dawson's 54-yard field goal. In the third quarter, Cleveland took the lead as QB [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Derek Anderson]] completed a 28-yard TD pass to WR [[Braylon Edwards]] and a 7-yard TD pass to RB [[Jason Wright]]. The Ravens responded with FB [[Le'Ron McClain]]'s 1-yard TD run. In the fourth quarter, Baltimore rallied as Flacco completed a 28-yard TD pass to WR [[Derrick Mason]], Stover kicking a 22-yard field goal, and LB [[Terrell Suggs]] returning an interception 42 yards for a touchdown. With the loss, the Browns fell to 3â5. ====Scoring Summary==== '''1st Quarter''' * 10:43 BAL â [[Matt Stover|Stover]] 41 yard field goal 3â0 BAL * 5:28 BAL â [[Mark J. Clayton|Clayton]] 47 yard pass from [[Joe Flacco|Flacco]] (Stover kick) 10â0 BAL * 5:19 CLE â [[Josh Cribbs|Cribbs]] 92 yard kickoff return ([[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] kick) 10â7 BAL '''2nd Quarter''' * 5:53 CLE â Dawson 23 yard field goal 10â10 * 0:32 BAL â Stover 32 yard field goal 13â10 BAL * 0:07 CLE â Dawson 54 yard field goal 13â13 '''3rd Quarter''' * 13:13 CLE â [[Braylon Edwards|Edwards]] 28 yard pass from [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Anderson]] (Dawson kick) 20â13 CLE * 6:17 CLE â [[Jason Wright|Wright]] 7 yard pass from Anderson (Dawson kick) 27â13 CLE * 1:15 BAL â [[Le'Ron McClain|McClain]] 1 yard run (Stover kick) 27â20 CLE '''4th Quarter''' * 14:07 BAL â [[Derrick Mason|Mason]] 28 yard pass from Flacco (Stover kick) 27â27 * 5:40 BAL â Stover 22 yard field goal 30â27 BAL * 2:52 BAL â [[Terrell Suggs|Suggs]] 42 yard interception return (Stover kick) 37â27 BAL ====Quinn Named Starter==== On November 3, it was announced that quarterback Derek Anderson would be benched in favor of QB [[Brady Quinn]] for the Browns' next game against the [[Denver Broncos]].[http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9077 Quinn to start Thursday] {{dead link|date=September 2011}} ===Week 10: vs. Denver Broncos=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Broncos''' |R1=7 |R2=3 |R3=3 |R4=21 |RT=34 |Home=Browns |H1=7 |H2=13 |H3=3 |H4=7 |HT=30 |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 8:15 PM EST |weather= 56 Â°F (Clear) |attendance= 73,141 |referee= [[Bill Leavy]] |TV=[[NFL Network]] | TVAnnouncers=[[Bob Papa]] & [[Cris Collinsworth]] }} [[File:BrownsvsBroncos11-06-08.jpg|right|225px|thumb|Cleveland Browns vs. Denver Broncos, November 6, 2008]] Hoping to rebound from their season-sweeping loss to the Ravens, the Browns stayed at home for a Week 10 Thursday night game against the [[Denver Broncos]]. In the first quarter, Cleveland trailed early as Broncos RB [[Ryan Torain]] got a 1-yard TD run. The Browns would respond as QB [[Brady Quinn]], making his first career start, completed a 5-yard TD pass to TE [[Kellen Winslow II|Kellen Winslow]]. In the second quarter, Cleveland took the lead as kicker [[Phil Dawson]] made a 24-yard field goal, along with Quinn hooking up with Winslow again on a 16-yard TD pass. Denver would answer with kicker [[Matt Prater]] making a 35-yard field goal. The Browns would close out the half with Dawson making a 52-yard field goal. In the third quarter, Cleveland added onto its lead as Dawson got a 33-yard field goal. The Broncos would reply with Prater making a 30-yard field. In the fourth quarter, Denver regained the lead as QB [[Jay Cutler (American football)|Jay Cutler]] completing a 93-yard TD pass to WR [[Eddie Royal]] and a 27-yard TD pass to TE [[Daniel Graham]]. The Browns would respond with RB [[Jamal Lewis]] getting a 1-yard TD run. However, the Broncos replied with Cutler completing an 11-yard TD pass to WR [[Brandon Marshall]]. Cleveland tried to come back, but Denver's defense stiffened. With the loss, the Browns fell to 3â6, making it impossible to improve on their 10â6 record from the 2007 season. This also marked Cleveland's eighth-straight loss to Denver. Even with the loss the Cleveland Browns saw an upside to that game: Quinn showed that he could be the new face of Cleveland football. ====Scoring Summary==== '''1st Quarter''' * 7:08 DEN â [[Ryan Torain|Torain]] 1 yard run ([[Matt Prater|Prater]] kick) 7â0 DEN * 3:47 CLE â [[Kellen Winslow II|Winslow]] 5 yard pass from [[Brady Quinn|Quinn]] ([[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] kick) 7â7 '''2nd Quarter''' * 12:48 CLE â Dawson 24 yard field goal 10â7 CLE * 10:36 CLE â Winslow 16 yard pass from Quinn (Dawson kick) 17â7 CLE * 5:55 DEN â Prater 35 yard field goal 17â10 CLE * 1:14 CLE â Dawson 52 yard field goal 20â10 CLE '''3rd Quarter''' * 10:25 CLE â Dawson 33 yard field goal 23â10 CLE * 5:40 DEN â Prater 30 yard field goal 23â13 CLE '''4th Quarter''' * 13:43 DEN â [[Eddie Royal|Royal]] 93 yard pass from [[Jay Cutler (American football)|Cutler]] (Prater kick) 23â20 CLE * 10:00 DEN â [[Daniel Graham|Graham]] 27 yard pass from Cutler (Prater kick) 27â23 DEN * 5:00 CLE â [[Jamal Lewis|Lewis]] 1 yard run (Dawson kick) 30â27 CLE * 1:17 DEN â [[Brandon Marshall|Marshall]] 11 yard pass from Cutler (Prater kick) 34â30 DEN ===Week 11: at Buffalo Bills=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Browns''' |R1=6 |R2=7 |R3=3 |R4=13 |RT=29 |Home=Bills |H1=0 |H2=10 |H3=3 |H4=14 |HT=27 |stadium= [[Ralph Wilson Stadium]], [[Orchard Park (town), New York|Orchard Park, New York]] |time= 8:30 PM EST |weather= 30 Â°F (Partly Cloudy) |attendance= 71,645 |referee= [[Jerome Boger]] |TV=[[Monday Night Football|ESPN]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Mike Tirico]], [[Ron Jaworski]], [[Tony Kornheiser]], [[Michele Tafoya]], & [[Suzy Kolber]] }} Trying to snap a two-game losing streak, the Browns flew to [[Ralph Wilson Stadium]] for a Week 11 MNF duel with the [[Buffalo Bills]]. In the first quarter, Cleveland took advantage of early Bills miscues as kicker [[Phil Dawson]] kicked two field goals. In the second quarter, the Browns increased their lead as Josh Cribbs scored a 2-yard TD run. Buffalo responded with QB [[Trent Edwards]] completing an 18-yard TD pass to RB [[Marshawn Lynch]], along with kicker [[Rian Lindell]] getting a 26-yard field goal. In the third quarter, Cleveland answered with Dawson getting a 43-yard field goal. The Bills would reply with Lindell making a 31-yard field goal. In the fourth quarter, the Browns greatly answered with RB [[Jerome Harrison]] getting a 72-yard TD run. Buffalo would immediately respond with CB [[Leodis McKelvin]] returning a kickoff 98 yards for a touchdown and would take the lead on a 1-yard TD run by Edwards. Afterwards, the Browns regained the lead as Dawson nailed a 56-yard field goal. Buffalo did try to make a comeback, yet Lindell's 47-yard field goal sailed wide right, preserving Cleveland's victory and preventing them from becoming the first NFL team to lose three straight games after having a lead of 13 or more points in each of them. With the win, the Browns improved to 4â6. ====Scoring Summary==== '''1st Quarter''' * 9:29 CLE â [[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] 40 yard field goal 3â0 CLE * 2:28 CLE â Dawson 33 yard field goal 6â0 CLE '''2nd Quarter''' * 9:52 CLE â [[Josh Cribbs|Cribbs]] 2 yard run (Dawson kick) 13â0 CLE * 6:20 BUF â [[Marshawn Lynch|Lynch]] 18 yard pass from [[Trent Edwards|Edwards]] ([[Rian Lindell|Lindell]] kick) 13â7 CLE * 0:00 BUF â Lindell 26 yard field goal 13â10 CLE '''3rd Quarter''' * 6:27 CLE â Dawson 43 yard field goal 16â10 CLE * 0:22 BUF â Lindell 31 yard field goal 16â13 CLE '''4th Quarter''' * 14:47 CLE â [[Jerome Harrison|Harrison]] 72 yard run (Dawson kick) 23â13 CLE * 14:33 BUF â [[Leodis McKelvin|McKelvin]] 98 yard kickoff return (Lindell kick) 23â20 CLE * 11:32 CLE â Dawson 22 yard field goal 26â20 CLE * 2:25 BUF â Edwards 1 yard run (Lindell kick) 27â26 BUF * 1:39 CLE â Dawson 56 yard field goal 29â27 CLE ====Phil Savage E-Mail controversy==== Browns General Manager [[Phil Savage]] received a lot of criticism when he received an [[e-mail]] from a Browns fans during the Bills game, which read the following:
''You are easily the worst GM in the NFL. [[Rob Chudzinski|Chud]], [[Romeo Crennel|Crennel]] and [[Mel Tucker|Tucker]] should NOT have jobs. How the hell do you play prevent defense the entire game? How do you NOT use [[Jerome Harrison]] more? Why the hell would you throw the ball with 6 minutes left? This is officially a regime that is worse than [[Butch Davis]]'. By the way, just like last week â this email was written while the Browns still had the lead.'' [http://deadspin.com/5093632/browns-gm-phil-savage-responds-to-email-hecklers-swiftly-but-not-very-politely Browns' GM Phil Savage Responds To Email Hecklers Swiftly, But Not Very Politely (UPDATE)]
After the game, Savage promptly responded back to the fan with the following:
''Go root for Buffalo-[[fuck|f#@*]] you'' [http://www.profootballtalk.com/2008/11/19/savage-gets-testy/comment-page-2/ ProFootballTalk] ===Week 12: vs. Houston Texans=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Texans''' |R1=7 |R2=6 |R3=3 |R4=0 |RT=16 |Home=Browns |H1=0 |H2=6 |H3=0 |H4=0 |HT=6 |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 1:00 PM EST |weather= 30 Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 72,077 |referee= [[Ed Hochuli]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] | TVAnnouncers=[[Kevin Harlan]] & [[Rich Gannon]] }} Coming off their MNF road win over the Bills, the Browns went home for a Week 12 duel with the [[Houston Texans]]. In the first quarter, Cleveland trailed early as Texans QB [[Sage Rosenfels]] completed a 17-yard TD pass to WR [[Kevin Walter]]. In the second quarter, Houston increased its lead as kicker [[Kris Brown]] got a 31-yard field goal. The Browns would respond with kicker [[Phil Dawson]] getting a pair of 32-yard field goals, but the Texans answered with Brown's 31-yard field goal. In the third quarter, Houston kept its momentum going with Brown nailing a 31-yard field goal. Cleveland tried to rally, but Houston's defense was too much. With the loss, the Browns fell to 4â7. ====Scoring Summary==== '''1st Quarter''' * 6:55 HOU â [[Kevin Walter|Walter]] 17 yard pass from [[Sage Rosenfels|Rosenfels]] ([[Kris Brown|Brown]] kick) 7â0 HOU '''2nd Quarter''' * 13:43 HOU â Brown 31 yard field goal 10â0 HOU * 8:03 CLE â [[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] 32 yard field goal 10â3 HOU * 2:24 CLE â Dawson 32 yard field goal 10â6 HOU * 0:07 HOU â Brown 31 yard field goal 13â6 HOU '''3rd Quarter''' * 8:53 HOU â Brown 36 yard field goal 16â6 HOU ====Quinn out for season==== On November 25, it was announced that quarterback [[Brady Quinn]] would be out for the season due to a fractured right index finger suffered in the Browns' week 11 duel with the Buffalo Bills. [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Derek Anderson]] was announced to be the starter for their next game against the Indianapolis Colts.[http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9199 Quinn done for the season] {{dead link|date=September 2011}} ===Week 13: vs. Indianapolis Colts=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Colts''' |R1=3 |R2=0 |R3=0 |R4=7 |RT=10 |Home=Browns |H1=3 |H2=3 |H3=0 |H4=0 |HT=6 |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 1:00 PM EST |weather= 36 Â°F (Clouds & Rain) |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Enberg]] and [[Randy Cross]] |attendance= 72,411 |referee= [[Terry McAulay]] }} Hoping to rebound from their loss to the Texans, the Browns stayed at home for a Week 13 duel with the [[Indianapolis Colts]]. In the first quarter, Cleveland struck first as kicker [[Phil Dawson]] kicked a 34-yard field goal. The Colts answered with kicker [[Adam Vinatieri]] kicking a 30-yard field goal. In the second quarter, the Browns regained the lead as Dawson nailed a 25-yard field goal. However, after a scoreless third quarter, Indianapolis' defense answered in the fourth quarter, as DE [[Robert Mathis]] returned a fumble 37 yards for a touchdown. From there on out, Cleveland was unable to come back. With the loss, the Browns stumbled to 4â8. ====Scoring Summary==== '''1st Quarter''' * 9:09 CLE â [[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] 34 yard field goal 3â0 CLE * 2:02 IND â [[Adam Vinatieri|Vinatieri]] 30 yard field goal 3â3 '''2nd Quarter''' * 7:36 CLE â Dawson 25 yard field goal 6â3 CLE '''4th Quarter''' * 9:55 IND â [[Robert Mathis|Mathis]] 37 yard fumble return (Vinatieri kick) 10â6 IND ====Anderson out for season==== On December 1, it was announced that QB [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Derek Anderson]] would be done for the season following a torn MCL suffered in the loss to the Colts. Third-string QB [[Ken Dorsey]] was announced to be starting for the Browns' next game against the [[Tennessee Titans]].[http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9222 Anderson out for season] {{dead link|date=September 2011}}[http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9223 Dorsey prepared for task ahead] {{dead link|date=September 2011}} ====Bruce Gradkowski signed==== On December 2, the Browns signed free-agent veteran QB [[Bruce Gradkowski]] to a two-year contract. Gradkowski will serve as the backup QB under Dorsey for the Browns' next game against the Tennessee Titans.[http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3739884 Browns sign Gradkowski to two-year contract] ===Week 14: at Tennessee Titans=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Browns |R1=6 |R2=0 |R3=0 |R4=3 |RT=9 |Home='''Titans''' |H1=0 |H2=14 |H3=7 |H4=7 |HT=28 |stadium= [[LP Field]], [[Nashville, Tennessee]] |time= 1:00 PM EST |weather= 32 Â°F (Sunny) |referee= [[Ron Winter]] |attendance= 69,143 |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Don Criqui]] & [[Dan Fouts]] }} Trying to rebound from back-to-back home losses, the Browns flew to [[LP Field]] for a Week 14 duel with the [[Tennessee Titans]]. Cleveland struck first in the opening quarter as kicker [[Phil Dawson]] got a 47-yard and a 41-yard field goal. The Titans took the lead in the second quarter, as QB [[Kerry Collins]] completed a 28-yard touchdown pass to FB [[Ahmard Hall]], along with RB [[LenDale White]] got a 3-yard touchdown run. Tennessee would increase its lead in the third quarter as Collins completed a 9-yard touchdown to wide receiver [[Justin Gage]]. In the fourth quarter, the Browns to rally as Dawson nailed a 39-yard field goal, yet the Titans pulled away as RB [[Chris Johnson (running back)|Chris Johnson]] got a 25-yard touchdown run. With the loss, Cleveland fell to 4â9. ====Scoring Summary==== '''1st Quarter''' * 11:58 CLE â [[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] 47 yard field goal 3â0 CLE * 4:00 CLE â Dawson 41 yard field goal 6â0 CLE '''2nd Quarter''' * 14:10 TEN â [[Ahmard Hall|Hall]] 28 yard pass from [[Kerry Collins|Collins]] ([[Rob Bironas|Bironas]] kick) 7â6 TEN * 1:11 TEN â [[LenDale White|White]] 3 yard run (Bironas kick) 14â6 TEN '''3rd Quarter''' * 11:46 TEN â [[Justin Gage|Gage]] 9 yard pass from Collins (Bironas kick) 21â6 TEN '''4th Quarter''' * 13:30 CLE â Dawson 39 yard field goal 21â9 TEN * 8:22 TEN â [[Chris Johnson (running back)|Johnson]] 25 yard run (Bironas kick) 28â9 TEN ===Week 15: at Philadelphia Eagles=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Browns |R1=3||R2=0||R3=0||R4=7||RT=10 |Home='''Eagles''' |H1=10||H2=7||H3=3||H4=10||HT=30 |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 8:30 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= |attendance= |referee= |TV=[[Monday Night Football|ESPN]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Mike Tirico]], [[Ron Jaworski]], [[Tony Kornheiser]], [[Michele Tafoya]], & [[Suzy Kolber]] }} Coming off three straight losses without a touchdown, the Cleveland Browns sought to go 3â0 on Monday Night games, this time ON THE ROAD against the [[Philadelphia Eagles]]. The Eagles struck first with a touchdown pass to WR [[Kevin Curtis]]. Both teams also traded field goals in the first quarter. CB [[Asante Samuel]] extended the Eagles' lead in the second quarter with an interception return for a touchdown, and K [[David Akers]] added a field goal in the third quarter. Cleveland could not answer, but DB [[Brandon McDonald]] scored the first touchdown for the Browns in 4 games with an interception return in the fourth quarter. This game saw the Browns extend their offensive troubles, going 16 quarters without an offensive touchdown. With the loss, the Browns fell to 4â10, the third time in four years under Romeo Crennel that the Browns have had double-digit losses. ====Scoring Summary==== '''1st Quarter''' * 10:45 PHI â [[Kevin Curtis|Curtis]] 14 yard pass from [[Donovan McNabb|McNabb]] ([[David Akers|Akers]] kick) 7â0 PHI * 6:48 CLE â [[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] 27 yard field goal 7â3 PHI * 0:49 PHI â Akers 24 yard field goal 10â3 PHI '''2nd Quarter''' * 4:45 PHI â [[Asante Samuel|Samuel]] 50 yard interception return (Akers kick) 17â3 PHI '''3rd Quarter''' * 3:34 PHI â Akers 34 yard field goal 20â3 PHI '''4th Quarter''' * 14:52 PHI â Akers 34 yard field goal 23â3 PHI * 11:14 PHI â [[Greg Lewis (wide receiver)|Lewis]] 10 yard pass from McNabb (Akers kick) 30â3 PHI * 9:11 CLE â [[Brandon McDonald|McDonald]] 24 yard interception return (Dawson kick) 30â10 PHI ===Week 16: vs. Cincinnati Bengals=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Bengals''' |R1=7||R2=7||R3=0||R4=0||RT=0 |Home=Browns |H1=0||H2=0||H3=0||H4=0||HT=0 |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 0 Â°F (Wind Chill: -20 Â°F) |attendance= 72,361 |referee= [[Mike Carey (American football)|Mike Carey]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] | TVAnnouncers=[[Kevin Harlan]] & [[Rich Gannon]] }} Coming off four straight losses in which their offense failed to score a touchdown, the Cleveland Browns played their final home game of the season in near-zero wind chills against the [[Cincinnati Bengals]]. The Bengals scored first, with CB [[Leon Hall]] intercepting a [[Ken Dorsey]] pass and returning it 50 yards for a touchdown in the first quarter. WR [[Chris Henry (wide receiver)|Chris Henry]] completed the scoring by adding on a 20 yard touchdown reception in the second quarter. The shutout marked five straight games in which Cleveland's offense couldn't find the end zone. The only bright spot for the Browns was RB [[Jamal Lewis]], who became the 24th NFL player to reach 10,000 career rushing yards. With the loss, the Browns fell to 4â11, and ended the season 1â7 at home. ====Scoring Summary==== '''1st Quarter''' * 8:39 CIN â [[Leon Hall|Hall]] 50 yard interception return ([[Shayne Graham|Graham]] kick) 7â0 CIN '''2nd Quarter''' * 8:08 CIN â [[Chris Henry (wide receiver)|Henry]] 20 yard pass from [[Ryan Fitzpatrick|Fitzpatrick]] (Graham kick) 14â0 CIN ===Week 17: at Pittsburgh Steelers=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Browns |R1=0||R2=0||R3=0||R4=0||RT=0 |Home='''Steelers''' |H1=0||H2=14||H3=3||H4=14||HT=0 |stadium= [[Heinz Field]], [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 48 Â°F (Cloudy) |attendance= 63,553 |referee= [[Jeff Triplette]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Gus Johnson (sportscaster)|Gus Johnson]] & [[Steve Tasker]] }} Coming off five straight losses without a touchdown on offense, the Cleveland Browns closed out the regular season at [[Heinz Field]] in a Week 17 AFC North rematch with their hated rival, the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]]. The Steelers put up two touchdowns in the second quarter, a 34 yard run by RB [[Willie Parker]] and an 8 yard scramble by QB [[Byron Leftwich]]. The Steelers added 17 points in the second half (22-yard [[Jeff Reed (American football)|Jeff Reed]] field goal, 3-yard [[Gary Russell (American football)|Gary Russell]] touchdown run, and a 32-yard interception TD return by [[Tyrone Carter]]), but they were unnecessary as the Browns were incapable of scoring at all, marking six straight games in which the offense couldn't score a touchdown (an NFL record 24 quarters). Again, the only good news for the Browns was RB [[Jamal Lewis]], who topped 1,000 rushing yards this season. He would become the first Browns running back since [[Mike Pruitt]] in 1980 & 1981 to have back-to-back 1,000-yard rushing seasons. With the loss, the Browns ended their season at 4â12, with a record of 3â5 away from home. This also marked the Browns' eleventh straight loss to the Steelers. ====Scoring Summary==== '''2nd Quarter''' * 4:15 PIT â [[Willie Parker|Parker]] 34 yard run ([[Jeff Reed (American football)|Reed]] kick) 7â0 PIT * 0:40 PIT â [[Byron Leftwich|Leftwich]] 8 yard run (Reed kick) 14â0 PIT '''3rd Quarter''' * 5:39 PIT â Reed 22 yard field goal 17â0 PIT '''4th Quarter''' * 9:45 PIT â [[Gary Russell (American football)|Russell]] 3 yard run (Reed kick) 24â0 PIT * 8:52 PIT â [[Tyrone Carter|Carter]] 32 yard interception return (Reed kick) 31â0 PIT ====Savage and Crennel fired==== After the game, it was announced that GM [[Phil Savage]] was fired. One day later, head coach [[Romeo Crennel]] would also be released after the Browns ended their season at 4â12, at the bottom of the AFC North. ==2009 Pro Bowl== Despite the disappointing performance by the team, LT [[Joe Thomas (American football)|Joe Thomas]], DT [[Shaun Rogers (American football)|Shaun Rogers]], and LS [[Ryan Pontbriand]] were recognized for individual accomplishments as they were named to the AFC roster for the [[2009 Pro Bowl]]. Thomas and Rogers were selected by the pro-bowl voters{{cite web|author=Jackson, Zac|date=16 December 2008|title=Thomas, Rogers Headed to Hawaii|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9282|accessdate=16 December 2008|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20081220101745/http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9282 |archivedate = December 20, 2008|deadurl=yes}} ., and Pontbriand was selected as a "need" player by the [[Baltimore Ravens]] coaching staff, who will be coaching the AFC squad.{{cite web|author=Jackson, Zac|date=28 January 2009|title=Pontbriand added to Pro Bowl roster|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9391|accessdate=30 January 2009|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20090203072917/http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9391 |archivedate = February 03, 2009|deadurl=yes}} KR Josh Cribbs was named a first alternate, K [[Phil Dawson]] a second alternate, and LG [[Eric Steinbach]] and LB [[D'Qwell Jackson]] were named third alternates at their respective positions. == References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Cleveland Browns}} {{Cleveland Browns seasons}} {{2008 NFL season by team}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2008 Cleveland Browns Season}} [[Category:Cleveland Browns seasons]] [[Category:2008 National Football League season by team|Cleveland]]
